content: Telecom isn't a high earnings- or revenue-growth sector, even though wireless and broadband services are "must-haves" for U.S. consumers. Stocks often run up on merger and acquisition speculation, while tougher regulation can be a worry.X Big cap telecom stocks such as AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) have attractive dividends. And, telecom stocks are sometimes viewed as a safe haven when stock markets turn volatile.T-Mobile US (TMUS) has grabbed subscriber and revenue market share amid speculation it'll be part of wireless industry consolidation. Comcast (CMCSA)'s institutional ownership has been rising as it delivers growth from broadband services and media arm NBCUniversal.Bookmark this page to stay on top of companies such as Charter Communications (CHTR), Sprint (S), Dish Network (DISH), and CenturyLink (CTL). Also note that telecom developments often impact media stocks such as Walt Disney (DIS), Discovery Communications (DISCA) and 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOX).Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.RELATED:Best Stocks To Buy And WatchWhich Stocks Are Showing Rising Relative Strength?

Add Apple (AAPL) and AT&T (T) to the growing list of U.S. technology stocks that could be impacted by a rising U.S. dollar when they report earnings.China's yuan on Monday fell to its lowest level against the U.S. dollar since mid-August 2017. China is a key market for Apple's iPhone sales.In a report on Monday, Morgan Stanley cited telecom companies with exposure to the rising U.S. dollar."Weaker currencies vs. the U.S. dollar have a been a consistent topic in recent months and are likely to be a headwind to guidance/consensus estimates," Morgan Stanley analyst Simon Flannery said in a note to clients. The impact could come, he added, "as we move through second-quarter earnings season, particularly for American Tower (AMT), SBA Communications (SBAC) and Equinix (EQIX)."Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseIn AT&T's case, Flannery notes the exposure of its wireless business in Mexico as well as its satellite TV business. DirecTV sells pay-TV services in Brazil. The U.S. dollar has strengthened against currencies from Brazil, Mexico and Canada, the analyst said.AT&T recently updated financial guidance, following its purchase of Time Warner. AT&T stock closed up 0.3% to 32.21 in the stock market today. Apple rose 1.1% to 187.18.Shares in American Tower edged up 0.4% to 144.67. to 143.07. SBA Communications slipped 0.3% to 164.69. Equinix, a data center operator, was down 0.4% to 428.21.The euro and British pound also have weakened vs. the dollar.Other companies to watch include Zayo (ZAYO) and CenturyLink (CTL), Flannery said.Akamai Technologies (AKAM) and Red Hat (RHT), an enterprise software provider, recently lowered revenue guidance. Akamai and Red Hat cited the strengthening dollar.Technology stocks, including Apple, got a boost from a weak dollar in the March quarter and in late 2017. Aside from impacting overseas earnings, a rising dollar also makes U.S. products more expensive.China's yuan suffered its worst ever month against the dollar in June. China is a key market for Apple, as is India. Apple may not feel the impact until its September quarter."More recently the Indian rupee has fallen to record lows on concerns over trade and oil prices," Flannery said.Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.RELATED LINKS:Sell And Take Profits Or Hold? Here Are Several Guidelines To FollowStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth StocksThe Basics: How To Analyze A Stock's Cup With HandleHow To Find Great Growth Stocks: Learn To Spot The Flat Base, A Bullish Chart Pattern

Infinera (INFN) stock switched gears and plunged Thursday after the company's earnings call with analysts raised worries over pricing pressure and spending by a key customer.Shares in Infinera crashed by 20.5% to close at 9.35 on the stock market today after rising as much as 7% after the company reported first-quarter results late Wednesday. Shares in rival Ciena (CIEN) fell 3.6% to 25.91. Ciena reports its fiscal second-quarter earnings on May 31.Management renewed worries over aggressive pricing by competitors on the company's quarterly call late Wednesday."We view a return to long-term margin target of 50% as still several years out despite an improved revenue trajectory," said Jeffrey Kvaal, an Instinet analyst in a report.Phone company CenturyLink (CTL), a key customer, also is a concern.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"There still remains skepticism regarding spending from their top customer, CenturyLink, and if that will rebound at all in 2018," said Troy Jensen, a Piper Jaffray analyst in a report.Infinera reported an adjusted loss of 5 cents a share, narrowing its loss from a year earlier. Revenue surged 16% to $202.7 million, topping consensus estimates.A year earlier, Infinera reported a loss of 15 cents a share on sales of $175 million. Analysts expected Infinera to report a loss of 11 cents a share on sales of $201 million for the period ended March 31.For the June quarter, Infinera said it expects revenue of $208 million at its midpoint of guidance vs. estimates of $205 million. Infinera forecast earnings in a range of a 5-cent loss to a 2-cent profit vs. estimates of a 6-cent loss.Ciena and Infinera make system-level optical products. IBD's Telecom-Fiber Optics group is ranked No. 64 out of 197 industry groups.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Sell And Take Profits Or Hold? Here Are Several Guidelines To FollowChart-Reading Basics: How A Buy Point Marks A Time Of Real Opportunity

There's only been one S&P 500 sector with a negative return since Donald Trump took office as president, and that's telecom.X The S&P 500 Telecommunications Services sector, which includes AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ), as of Friday's market close was down by more than 7% in the 12 months since Trump's inauguration, said Howard Silverblatt, a senior analyst at S&P Dow Jones Indices, on Twitter (TWTR). AT&T was down 10% since Jan. 20, 2017, with Verizon down about 1%. CenturyLink (CTL) has  plunged 32%.Other poorly performing sectors were energy, utilities and real estate. All had low single-digit gains.The Information Technology sector, led by most of the FANG  stocks (Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL)-Google) stocks, shot up over 43% as of Friday's market close.Netflix had gained 60%, Amazon 58%, Facebook 40%, and Google 35%. Apple (AAPL), meanwhile, was up 51% since Trump took office while Tesla (TSLA) jumped 40%Financials, health-care, consumer discretionary, materials and industrials  were among high-performing  sectors that notched stock returns in the mid- to high 20s, said Silverblatt in a tweet.Total stock market wealth added since Trump's inauguration: $5.5 trillion, says CNBC.IBD'S TAKE: Finding the best stocks to buy can be tricky. That's why Investor's Business Daily makes it easy with educational tools, stock lists, research, Leaderboard and more.Netflix, Facebook and Google as well as AT&T and Verizon, will be in the same S&P 500 industry sector starting in September, a big change relevant for investors in index funds and ETFs. They will be part of the renamed Communications Services sector, S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI announced recently.Aside from the internet companies, the new Communications Services sector also includes cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA), Dish Network (DISH), Walt Disney (DIS), Twitter, and Snap (SNAP).RELATED COVERAGE:Workday, These Three Energy Stocks Are Near Buy Points In First-Stage BasesBitcoin, Blockchain And Private Industry: You Ain't Seen Nothing YetFANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, Google

Three FANG stocks and two telecom giants are now in the same industry sector, a big change relevant for investors in index funds and ETFs.Dividend-paying AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ), along with high-growth internet stocks Netflix (NFLX), Facebook (FB) and Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google, now belong to the renamed Communications Services sector, S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI announced late Thursday.Amazon.com (AMZN), also part of the closely-watched tech FANG stocks with Facebook, Netflix and Google, was not added to the Communications Services sector.Previously called the Telecommunication Services sector, the group has included only phone companies such as AT&T, Verizon and CenturyLink (CTL). Aside from the internet companies, the new Communications Services sector also includes cable TV firm Comcast (CMCSA), Dish Network (DISH), Walt Disney (DIS), Twitter (TWTR), and Snap (SNAP).S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI said in November 2017 that they were planning changes to the Global Industry Classification Standard categories. The changes take effect on Sept. 28. S&P Dow Jones Indices and MSCI say the changes reflect blurring lines between media, internet and telecom companies.IBD'S TAKE: Finding the best stocks to buy can be tricky. That's why Investor's Business Daily makes it easy with educational tools, stock lists, research, Leaderboard and more.AT&T is seeking approval to acquire Time Warner (TWX).Comcast, Netflix, Disney and Dish are now part of the Consumer Discretionary sector, while Alphabet, Facebook and Snap are currently in the Information Technology sector.RELATED:Blackrock Earnings Top As ETF Demand Pushes Assets $6 TrillionFANG Stocks News & Quotes: Facebook, Amazon, Netflix, GoogleFacebook Stock Dives Below Buy Point As News Feed Aims To Be Less 'Relevant'These Are The Five Strongest Industry Groups In 2018

Stocks opened higher Wednesday, with tech stocks taking an early lead ahead of this afternoon's Federal Reserve announcement.XThe Dow Jones industrial average opened up 0.1%, with Caterpillar (CAT) up 1.3% and Apple (AAPL) taking a 0.9% gain.The Nasdaq Composite jumped 0.4%, bolstered by strong early moves from Western Digital (WDC) and NetEase (NTES).The S&P 500 climbed 0.2%, with Western Digital, CenturyLink (CTL) and Dentsply Sirona (XRAY) chalking up the strongest gains.The focal point for Wednesday's action is likely to be the announcement of the Federal Open Market Committee's rate policy decision at 2 p.m. Markets fully expect a rate hike, with CME Group's FedWatch showing a 90.2% probability of a quarter-point hike and a 9.8% chance of a half-point hike. The larger question is how many additional rate increases Fed policymakers deem necessary for 2018, a projection that is seen largely as a referendum on the GOP's tax reform package.Consumer prices rose 0.4% in November, the Labor Department estimated, upshifting from a 0.1% increase in October and meeting economists' consensus projections. Core prices, without energy or food, rose 0.1%, down from October's 0.2% advance and also in line with expectations.The Energy Information Administration reports weekly oil inventories at 10:30 a.m. ET.Caterpillar powered up 2%, with an eye toward reversing a mild, two-day pullback. Shares remained in a buy range Tuesday, above a 140.54 buy point in a flat base. Barclays initiated coverage on the stock with an overweight rating.Walt Disney dipped 0.2%, while 21st Century Fox sank more than 2%, two days after Comcast (CMCSA) retracted its bid for Fox's TV and movie studio assets. That left Disney as the sole bidder in what some expect to be a $60 billion deal. News reports said the two companies plan to announce an agreement on Thursday. Disney shares climbed back above support this week, almost 12% above a September low and working their way up the right side of a possible eight-month base pattern.Fox shares were up 8% from a 31.02 buy point in a cup-with-handle base at the end of Tuesday's session.Fiber optic gear maker Finisar (FNSR) opened 26% higher, on reports that Appl had awarded the Sunnyvale, Calif., company $390 million out of its $1 billion Advanced Manufacturing Fund. The funds will enable Finisar to convert its dormant 700,000-square-foot plant in Sherman, Texas, into a production facility for VCSEL semiconductors, or vertical cavity surface emitting laser chips.

VCSEL competitor Lumentum (LITE) slumped 11% in early action.Western Digital surged nearly 4% at the open, after Summit Redstone Partners upgraded the stock to buy, from hold. Western settled a joint venture agreement dispute with Toshiba on Tuesday. The deal cleared Tohiba's path to the sale of its flash-memory unit to a group led by Bain Capital, which includes Apple and Dell Technologies (DVMT).Western Digital shares are below key support levels in a five-month consolidation.Verifone Systems (PAY) sunk 7% after meeting fiscal fourth-quarter performance expectations, but delivering first-quarter and full-year guidance below consensus views. The point-of-sale systems maker also announced a $100 million share buyback initiative. The stock was testing resistance at the end of Tuesday's session, attempting to climb the right side of a three month consolidation.Grupo Supervielle (SUPV) led the IBD 50 list, up 2% at of the open. The stock is extended after a November rebound from support at its 10-week moving average.RELATED:The Big Picture: This Key Tech Sector Shows Unusual Weakness5 Truck Stocks Set Up Buy Points Despite Tesla Semi: Investing Action PlanGOP Senate Majority Shrinks; Apple Carving New Base; Stock Futures

CenturyLink (CTL) reported third quarter profit and revenue below estimates, sending shares in the local and long-distance phone company down on renewed worries over its dividend to shareholders.Shares of the company fell nearly 5% to close at 15.48 on the stock market today.Late Wednesday CenturyLink said third-quarter adjusted earnings fell 25% to 42 cents a share while revenue fell 8% to $4.03 billion. Analysts had projected revenue of $4.06 billion and adjusted profit of 45 cents a share."With the past few quarters of inconsistency in both (local and long-distance) businesses, management will need the next few quarters to show investors successful operational execution, a smooth integration, and margin stability to instill confidence with investors that the dividend is safe," said Gregory Williams, a Cowen & Co. analyst in a report.Scott Goldman, analyst at Jefferies, said in a report: "Disappointing standalone results continue to highlight the challenges in stabilizing the business. Nevertheless, management reaffirmed commitment to the dividend. We were previously cautious on the dividend, and now see even less margin for error, though do not anticipate a cut in the near-term."CenturyLink on Nov. 1 completed its purchase of Level 3 Communications.CenturyLink Chief Executive Glen Post plans to run the company until 2019, when he hands over management over to Level 3's CEO, Jeff Storey.CenturyLink morphed into the nation's third-largest local phone company, behind Dow component Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT&T (T), by purchasing Qwest and Embarq.  Broomfield, Colo.-based Level 3 operates one of the world's largest internet backbones.

Stocks opened in tightly mixed trade and quickly faded to narrow losses Thursday, despite strong early moves by Wal-Mart (WMT) and Tesla (TSLA).XThe Dow Jones industrial average opened a fraction higher, then fell back to just below its breakeven line, fighting to hold above the 22,000 level that the index topped for the first time on Wednesday. The S&P 500 traded down 0.1% as drug distribution giant AmerisourceBergen (ABC) and CenturyLink (CTL) dropped more than 5% apiece after weak Q2 reports.The Nasdaq Composite notched an incremental decline, as Apple (AAPL) backed off 0.3% after its 5% breakout surge on Wednesday, and as all four FANG stocks posted early losses, led by Netflix's (NFLX) 0.6% slip.On the Dow, Wal-Mart and UnitedHealth (UNH) led the index. Wal-Mart jumped 1.1% at the open. UnitedHealth rose 1%. Caterpillar (CAT) opened up 0.3%, boosted by an upgrade to neutral, from underweight, by Atlantic Equities.Tesla shares racked up a 7% gain as the company's late-Wednesday report showed a smaller-than-forecast loss and above-forecast revenue growth. Tesla shares are consolidating and finding resistance at their 10-week moving average, but tight closes across the past three weeks suggest institutional support as the stock forms a possible floor to its basing effort.Online postage innovator Stamps.com (STMP) was an early hero, up 31% after reporting a solid beat, with second-quarter earnings up 61% and revenue soaring 38%, as management also lifted its full-year earnings and revenue guidance to above consensus views. The gap up gain left the IBD 50 stock extended after its first test of 10-week support since a breakout in late May.Another IBD 50 name, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), tacked on a 1% gain after reporting late Wednesday its second-quarter earnings swept past analyst targets. Revenue also topped views and management's sales guidance for Regeneron's Eyelea drug was better than expected.  The stock is working on the sixth week of a flat base, offering two buy points: at 526.22 and 543.65.Hotel operator Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) booked an early 3% gain. Single-digit growth in second-quarter revenue and earnings bested analyst estimates, and the company made official plans to split into two publicly traded entities. Wyndham shares were trading just below a 105.75 buy point in a five-week flat base.Aetna (AET) powered up 3% on strong second-quarter results, lifting shares easily to a new high.On the injured list, 3D Systems (DDD) fell 16% and Teva Pharmaceuticals (TEVA) skidded 19% lower after weak second-quarter reports.Early jobs data was positive, with employers announcing the layoffs of 28,307 workers in July, down 9% from June and the smallest count since November, according to the monthly jobs report from consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas. U.S. employers also announced 88,000 hirings, the best July total on record.First-time unemployment claims eased to 240,000 in the week ended July 29, the Labor Department reported. That was down 2% from the prior week's claims and below consensus views for 244,000 new applications. Claims have remained below 300,000 — generally considered the level showing a healthy jobs market — for 126 weeks.At 9:45 a.m. ET, IHS Markit delivers its service sector estimates for July. June factory orders numbers from the Commerce Department and the July services index from the Institute of Supply Management are due out at 10 a.m. ET.Overseas, markets across Asia booked broad losses Thursday with Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and the Nikkei 225 in Tokyo each falling 0.3%. In Europe, major indexes remained widely mixed in afternoon trade. London's FTSE 100 led with a 0.6% gain after the Bank of England elected to hold interest rates unchanged and trim its growth forecasts for the next two years. Frankfurt's DAX dropped 0.2%.RELATED:Get Your Grubhub On — And Your Game Face Too: Investing Action PlanThe Big Picture: Apple Breaks Out, But These 3 Factors Soured The DayThis Is Why Apple Is Bullish On Q4 Sales (It's Not The iPhone 8)

Shares in CenturyLink (CTL) surged Monday after hedge fund Corvex Management disclosed a stake in the local phone company, which is in the process of merging with Level 3 Communications (LVLT).Activist investor Corvex said it holds a 5.5% stake in CenturyLink at the Sohn Investment Conference in New York."It is our biggest position today," said Keith Meister, Corvex's founder and chief investment officer."CenturyLink is acquiring Level 3 and the acquisition is truly transformative," said Meister at the conference. He estimated the combined company will have $3 billion in annual free cash flow.Corves aims to have Level 3 Chief Executive Jeff Storey run the combined company in the long-run, the Wall Street Journal reported. CenturyLink Chief Executive Glen Post is set to be CEO of the merged company, with Storey a nonexecutive director.CenturyLink agreed to buy Level 3 in late October for $25 billion in cash and stock.CenturyLink morphed into the nation's third-largest local phone company, behind Dow component Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT&T (T), by purchasing Qwest and Embarq. Broomfield, Colo.-based Level 3 operates one of the world's largest internet backbones.IBD'S TAKE: CenturyLink pays a dividend, along with much bigger Verizon and AT&T. All phone companies are under pressure to sustain dividends amid slowing revenue growth, and the Level 3 deal should help, analysts say. Check out IBD's Income Investor for other high-dividend-paying stocks, such as banks, industrials and real estate investment trusts (REIT)s — although rising interest rates could hit them as well. Level 3 in 2014 acquired TW Telecom, becoming a stronger rival to AT&T and Verizon Communications in providing telecom services to businesses.Shares in CenturyLink ended 0.9% higherat 25.03 on the stock market today. Level 3 stock climbed 0.6% to 59.84.Neither CenturyLink or Level 3 Communications owns a wireless phone network.

Internet users have an insatiable need for speed — and that's been a boon for telecom infrastructure firms like Dycom Industries (DY).The voracious appetite for faster wireline and wireless networks is fueling the market that Dycom serves. Video, cloud-computing and Internet of Things applications are driving demand for more bandwidth on communications networks.So Dycom is benefiting from communications firms installing fiber-optic networks and wireless carriers upgrading to faster cellular networks like 5G."Several industry participants have articulated plans to deploy multigigabit speeds, while others are preparing to do so," Dycom CEO Steven Nielsen said on a recent call with analysts. "These industry developments have produced opportunities across a broad array of our existing customers, which in aggregate are without precedent for the industry in our experience."For Dycom, that should mean an extension of its winning streak. The Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.-based company — a provider of specialty contracting services in the U.S. and Canada to telecom companies as well as electric and gas utilities — has posted 20% or greater year-over-year sales growth for the last seven quarters.In its fiscal second quarter ended Jan. 28, Dycom earned 82 cents a share excluding items, up 52% from the year-earlier period, on sales that rose 25% to $701 million. The company's results were boosted by deployments of 1-gigabit wireline networks for key customers.Dycom's biggest customer is AT&T (T), which accounted for 28% of revenue in the second quarter. Other major clients include Comcast (CMCSA), CenturyLink (CTL), Dow Jones industrial average component Verizon Communications (VZ), Windstream (WIN) and Charter Communications (CHTR).The split of its business last quarter was 68.1% in telecom, 24.4% for cable, 4.9% in facility-locating services, and electrical and other making up the rest.But Wall Street is forecasting Dycom's growth to slow during the near term. It seems the company has been on such a roll, it's going up against difficult comparisons.For the April quarter, analysts are modeling Dycom to earn $1.19 a share, up 10%, on sales of $736.7 million, up 11%. For the July quarter, Wall Street is looking for Dycom to earn $1.79 a share, up 9%, on sales of $849.4 million, up 8%.Still, Dycom sees opportunities in emerging wireless technologies, such as 5G networks, over the near to intermediate term. In a plus for the company, the deployment of faster wireless networks also leads to a boost in associated fiber-optic wireline deployments at those locations.For instance, Verizon has embarked on a major, multi-city fiber deployment with the aim of building out a fiber network that will support all of the company's businesses, including the deployment of 5G wireless."We roughly size the initial phase of Verizon's fiber deployment at $5 billion to $7 billion over the next three years, which we believe could translate into $300 million-plus of annual incremental revenue opportunity for Dycom," Stifel analyst Noelle Dilts said in a report April 19. "This could translate into $47 million in EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) and 64 cents of EPS."And Verizon's project could be just the start, she said.IBD'S TAKE: Dycom Industries has an IBD Composite Rating of 97, meaning it has outperformed 97% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more information on Dycom, visit the IBD Stock Checkup."While the size of the opportunity associated with a Verizon fiber rollout is important, the implications for the competitive dynamics of the industry are arguably of greater significance, as AT&T, Comcast, Charter and others will have to respond to Verizon's move," Dilts said.Dilts rates Dycom stock as buy with a price target of 120.Investors have driven Dycom stock to record highs. Dycom hit an all-time high of 109.65 on April 25. It broke out of a cup base with a 98.57 buy point on April 18. Shares ended trading Friday up 2.3% to 107.84.Canaccord Genuity analyst Bobby Burleson also is bullish on Dycom. He rates the stock as buy with a price target of 120."Based on recent customer and supply-chain commentary, we believe Dycom is likely to continue to operate in a strengthening environment for fiber demand," Burleson said in an April 12 report. "Customers maintain healthy fiber deployment schedules, with multiyear build plans at cable (operators) and telcos still in early stages."Dycom expects to see initial deployments of 5G wireless systems this year and then ramping, Burleson said.Finally, FBR analyst Alex Rygiel rates Dycom as outperform with a price target of 120.The wireline infrastructure upgrade cycle is "in the early innings of increased spending" by telecom carriers and cable operators on 1-gigabit-per-second network deployments, Rygiel said in a note to clients.The analyst also raised his price target to 120 from 115 on March 2 after Dycom's second-quarter report, which beat consensus estimates for earnings per share and sales."The quarter was positively affected by strong 1 Gbps (gigabit-per-second) fiber deployments and market-share gains," Rygiel wrote. "The telecom wireline industry remains robust, with 1 Gbps deployments and the development of 5G technologies. We continue to believe that Dycom is the best-positioned contractor to benefit from these telecom trends, given its scale, market position, customer relationships and financial strength."

Altice USA, the U.S. arm of Netherlands-based multinational cable company Altice, filed plans for an initial public offering Tuesday, a prospect that could end up valuing the company at more than $20 billion.The Altice offering said it plans to raise $100 million, which is considered a placeholder for an IPO that could raise up to $1 billion, said Renaissance Capital.Altice USA has not yet determined how many shares it will offer or the price range of those shares, which will come at a later date. The Wall Street Journal said the IPO could value Altice USA at $20 billion, citing people familiar with the offering.  The lead underwriters are JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley.In its IPO prospectus, Altice USA said it's one of the largest broadband communications and video service providers in the U.S."We deliver broadband, pay television, telephony services, Wi-Fi hot spot access, proprietary content and advertising services to approximately 4.9 million residential and business customers," the prospectus said. Altice said its footprint extends across 21 states with more than 8.5 million homes passed.IBD'S TAKE: IBD focuses on the best-performing IPOs of the past three years in its IPO Leaders column. You can also read this Investor's Corner to maximize your chances for success with IPOs, or this article on finding today's top IPOs.Of its competitors, Altice said they include Verizon (VZ), AT&T (T) and its DirecTV subsidiary, CenturyLink (CTL), DISH Network (DISH) and Frontier Communications (FTR).Altice USA was formed in 2015 when the parent company closed its $9.1 billion purchase of a 70% stake of Suddenlink Communications and the $17.7 billion acquisition of Cablevision.RELATED:IPO Stock News And Analysis: Find Today's Top New IssuesOkta Prices At High End Of Range And Soars, Raising $187 Million

Comcast (CMCSA), Charter Communications (CHTR) and other cable TV firms are becoming broadband-first companies as they take away internet customers of AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ).The top cable companies added 3.3 million broadband subscribers in 2016 — similar to the gains in 2015, and the most net additions in any year since 2007, says Leichtman Research Group. Cable TV firms, meanwhile, lost 278,000 pay-TV video subscribers in 2016, although Comcast added 161,000.Comcast had 24.7 million broadband subscribers vs. 22.5 million video customers at the end of 2016. The broadband gap is wider at Charter, which acquired Time Warner Cable. Charter had 22.59 million broadband subscribers vs. 17.2 million video subscribers as of Dec. 31.The top cable TV firms followed by LRG had 58.4 million broadband subscribers vs. 48.6 million video subscribers at the end of 2016. Top telephone companies — including AT&T, Verizon and CenturyLink (CTL) — had 34.5 million broadband subscribers, down 599,000 from a year earlier. In 2015, phone companies lost 185,000 broadband subscribers, says LRG.With more internet video services rolling out in 2017 and next year, pay-TV industry subscribers could fall further, analysts say. As cord-cutting goes on and the traditional video business for cable providers shrinks, their No. 1 product will be broadband and internet access. So even if internet video takes off, they still have broadband dominance.IBD'S TAKE: Verizon and AT&T have been favorites of investors looking for high dividends, but there are other options, such as banks, industrials and real estate investment trusts (REITs). Check out IBD's Income Investor for high-dividend-paying stocksGoogle-parent Alphabet (GOOGL) has announced YouTube TV, a $35 monthly paid subscription service. Hulu — a joint venture of Walt Disney (DIS), Fox-parent 21st Century Fox Entertainment (FOXA) and Comcast's NBCUniversal — is set to launch yet another live TV streaming service in the spring. And, Amazon.com (AMZN) could follow in 2018.They'll join AT&T's DirecTV Now and Dish Network's (DISH) Sling streaming services.While cable TV firms outside of Comcast shed 278,000 video customers in 2016, phone companies lost 1.5 million, says LRG. AT&T's U-verse service accounted for 1.36 million subscriber losses as AT&T shifted marketing toward its DirecTV satellite TV service. DirecTV added 1.2 million customers last year, but Dish Network lost just over 1 million, says LRG.Comcast stock fell 0.5% to 37.47 in the stock market today. Comcast stock has been consolidating and is near a buy point of 38.54. Shares in AT&T rose 0.4% to 42.61 while Verizon stock climbed 0.7% to 50.39.RELATED:Will AT&T, Comcast, Verizon Seek Fees From YouTube TV, Hulu?

Infinera (INFN) stock jumped on views the optical communications device maker's revenue growth is rebounding, despite consolidation among customers such as XO Communications, Verizon Communications (VZ), Level 3 Communications (LVLT) and CenturyLink (CTL).Infinera stock soared 27% in the stock market today to a nearly six-month high of 11.96, after the company late Thursday reported a Q4 loss and lower revenue that nevertheless beat Wall Street expectations. The company reported strong demand for optical devices used in data centers to connect racks of computer servers, giving Q1 sales guidance that topped views."We now believe that the company has troughed, estimates have bottomed out and that Infinera is poised to rebound results," said Alex Henderson, a Needham analyst, in a research report.Infinera stock lagged in 2016, despite a run-up in other fiber optic stocks such as Lumentum Holdings (LITE), Finisar (FNSR), Ciena (CIEN) and Oclaro (OCLR). This week, Fabrinet (FN) Q2 earnings topped views, while Lumentum stock popped to record highs on both Wednesday and Thursday after executives on its earnings call made comments that led analysts to expect the company will ramp up 3D sensor products for customers such as Apple (AAPL).IBD'S TAKE: Weibo, Alibaba, Netflix and Glaukos are on IBD's Leaderboard, which follows top stocks from their work on forming bases, through their breakouts, to their post-breakout action, up to the point where they start topping.Lumentum stock rose 1.% on Friday, while Ciena rose 2.4%. IBD's 14-company Telecom-Fiber Optics group rose more than 2%, but it ranks just No. 160 out of 197 groups, down from No. 36 eight weeks ago.Infinera, meanwhile, reported that its Q4 swung to a 12-cent per-share loss minus items from a 5-cent profit in Q4 2015. Revenue fell 30% to $181 million. Analysts, though, had projected a 13-cent loss and revenue of $175.3 million."We sense the tone of business has shifted toward becoming more bullish with management noting several large wins in data center interconnect and metro this quarter," William Blair analyst Dmitry Netis said in his research report. "We continue to see the re-emergence of top-line growth and operating margin expansion in the second half of this year and into 2018."For the current quarter, Infinera forecast revenue of $167 million to $178 million, down from $249 million in Q1 2016, the midpoint just ahead of analyst consensus estimates of  $170.7 million. Infinera said it expects a loss of 16 cents per share as it hikes investments. Analysts had been modeling an 11-cent loss.George Notter, a Jefferies analyst, maintained a hold rating on Infinera stock."The organization is still emerging from a perfect storm of M&A-induced spending slowdowns affecting their largest customers," said Notter in a report. "We'll remain on the sidelines regarding the stock until we get better visibility into these fundamental product and customer improvements."RELATED:Lumentum Stock Breaks Out On Apple iPhone 3D Sensor Speculation

Stock funds seemed only slightly less frenetic than President Trump setting policy in his first 100 days, as the average domestic stock fund rose 1.83% in January, padding gains of 1.46% in December and 10.81% in 2016.World equity funds did even better in January, advancing 3.86%, according to Lipper Inc.Taxable bond funds rose 0.76%, while municipal bond funds rose 0.46%.The S&P 500 rose 1.90% last month.Not all of the young year's gains are attributable to the new president and new Congress, say stock fund managers and strategists."Regardless of who was elected, the economy was already improving," said Kimberly Scott, lead manager of $2.4 billion Ivy Mid Cap Growth (WMGAX) and co-manager of $288 million Ivy Mid Cap Income Opportunities (IVOAX) funds. "The trajectory of corporate profits had already turned up. The outlook for corporate profits for the end of 2017 into 2018 was already quite strong. The policy changes concerning taxes, repatriation of overseas corporate cash (and) unwinding some onerous regulations that President Trump talked about could boost corporate profits more. But the economy was already getting stronger."And mutual fund professionals expect the uptrend to continue this year."The market could go in two very different ways," said Omar Aguilar, Charles Schwab Investment Management's chief investment officer of equities. "On the one hand, there is a very powerful combination of factors that could translate into record levels for equities."On the other hand, the market could go south. "The attempt at reforms (of taxes, corporate cash repatriation and regulatory burdens) could increase the federal budget deficit," Aguilar said. "There is a potential for trade wars. Emerging markets are still landing. A strong U.S. currency could hurt exports. Those headwinds could backfire into our economy and markets."On balance, Aguilar is guardedly bullish. "On a net basis we will see the market trend up," he said. "But it will be volatile."Scott is favoring stocks in sectors that typically benefit at the outset of a rally. "Many think we're in the midcycle of a recovery," she said. "But we had a significant corporate-profits recession. So to me this feels like an early-stage economic recovery, and that's when you want to shift more asset weight into technology, financials, energy and industry."Consumer discretionary is usually part of that early-stage recovery party. But this time brick-and-mortar retailers are battling digital retailers. Brick-and-mortar retailers are being forced to spend on their own websites and low-cost delivery services, Scott says, which will continue to sap their earnings.Large-cap growth mutual funds' 4.10% gain on average in January led all U.S. diversified stock fund categories.Yet investors were still jittery enough at times to drive precious-metals funds, a defensive category, up 14.94% last month, higher than any other sector. That beat basic-materials funds, which gained 7.31%.Latin American funds paced foreign stock fund categories by tacking on 7.67%.Taxable bonds were led by flexible-income funds 1.61% gain. Treasury funds inched up 0.36%.Trailing precious metals and several other sector fund categories, tech funds notched a 5.13% January gain. IPG Photonics (IPGP) is a technology name that John Barr, manager of $60 million Needham Aggressive Growth (NEAGX) — whose 9.32% average annual gain over the past 10 years topped 96% of its small-cap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar Inc. — likes in a market poised to continue higher but with volatility. The company makes fiber-optic lasers, which can be used for cutting and welding in industrial applications. As costs fall, laser systems become increasingly attractive, especially in welding, Barr says. "Big automotive makers are quite interested in using this for welding," he said.Revenue grew 19% and 17% in the two most recent years. Earnings grew an average of 18% annually from 2014 to 2016. "It has a long runway ahead, with great returns and great management," Barr said.PDF Solutions (PDFS) is another tech name Barr likes. The firm produces software that's the core of electrical testing of newly made semiconductors. It has the potential for taking share from more conventional optical testing systems, Barr says.Two major chipmakers signed on as customers in 2016. PDF's service is delivered on a subscription basis. "So it has high margins and could double company earnings" in the near term, Barr said, especially if it wins customers in China as the Middle Kingdom builds out its own semiconductor manufacturing industry between now and 2020.Ivy's Scott likes MercadoLibre (MELI), an Argentina-based online retailer that offers an electronic payment service. "It's still in an earlier phase of development than Amazon (AMZN) is here," said Scott. "There is no reason to think that demand for online buying and payment will not be as attractive to Latin Americans as it is in the U.S. and Asia."Video-game publisher Electronic Arts (EA) is another of Scott's favorites. The video-game publisher benefits from a console-upgrade cycle and the shift to digital game downloads, which carry higher profit margins, as IBD has reported. Scott says now, "I continue to like the tremendous changes in the products and innovation there. They make games that consumers love. And the way that these products are developed and distributed digitally is such a profit enhancer. We think that story continues."Among financial services stocks, Scott likes regional banks such as First Republic (FRC) and Signature Bank (SBNY), which should benefit from rising rates and from a reduction in their regulatory burden. Trump targeted the Dodd-Frank Act for review on Friday.IBD'S TAKE: Midsize regional banks have gotten a boost from congressional moves to raise the threshold of the Dodd-Frank Act's systemic risk designation. The existing rule applies to banks with at least $50 billion in assets, subjecting them to costly regulations. As IBD recently reported, Congress is looking at raising that to $250 billion.Scott also likes MarketAxess Holdings (MKTX), an electronic bond-trading exchange that claims cheaper transaction costs than traditional investment-bank bond trades, easier odd-lot trading and specialization in corporate credit. "There are others trying to do this, but none has gained the traction that MarketAxess has," she said.Amid the rally in energy stocks, Stephen DeNichilo, co-manager of $2.9 billion Federated Kaufmann Large Cap (KLCAX), likes small-cap Independence Contract Drilling (ICD). The company offers customers of energy exploration and production very sophisticated drilling rigs. "They're on the leading edge of what E&P companies want," DeNichilo said. "They have only 12 working rigs, so essentially they are fully utilized. They have leverage to the U.S. shale-pad drilling rally. They have a clean balance sheet. They are trading below their $10-a-share replacement value. And they could be a takeout candidate."In addition to trading below 10, earnings per share growth has declined at triple-digit paces the past four quarters.Among industrials, DeNichilo likes Dycom Industries (DY). "We like long-term investment themes," DeNichilo said. "Dycom is the largest specialty contractor for fiber-(optic cable). They're the only national specialty contractor that puts fiber into the ground at a time when AT&T (T), CenturyLink (CTL), Charter (CHTR), Verizon (VZ) and other (telecoms) are about to ramp up."That cycle will be sparked, DeNichilo says, by AT&T embarking on a massive plan to lay fiber so the telecom giant can offer customers high-speed internet service. "Their plan is to bring 1-gigabit speed to (at least) 12 million customers by 2019," DeNichilo said. The industry has seen that when dramatically higher speeds are offered at the same or comparable cost, customers switch providers. "Competitors will have to follow," he said. "This will be a big cycle for Dycom. Also, fiber investments could be part of any large infrastructure (upgrade) plan by the government."At the average U.S. broadband speed of about 18 megabits, downloading a two-hour movie takes more than 10 minutes. It takes eight seconds via 1-Gig fiber, according to fastmetrics.com. And AT&T's speed upgrade can be achieved solely through street-side fiber, and will not require any in-home rewiring or cable replacement, DeNichilo says.Dycom's earnings grew an average of 74% annually over the past three years. "Despite earnings growth way above the market, they are trading below the market multiple," DeNichilo said.DeNichilo also likes Martin Marietta Materials (MLM). As the U.S. economy heats up, demand for construction aggregates will grow. "Even without Trump's Mexican wall, nonresidential construction — which is the bulk of aggregate consumption — is still below its 55-year normal level," he said. "This company has essentially doubled earnings per share over the past three years, so its outlook is fantastic whether there is a (federal government) infrastructure plan or not."Ivy's Scott likes water-heater-maker A.O. Smith (AOS). "There isn't a lot of cyclicality in their business," Scott said. "Homeowners have to replace their heaters every 10 to 12 years. And they have a growing business in China for water heaters and water-purification systems. It's a nice growth engine for Smith."Smith's average annual earnings growth rate was 24% from 2014 through 2016. "They're a consistent grower and reliable payer of dividends," Scott added. The company's dividend yield is 1.1%. "We're not a dividend fund, but it's nice to have on top of everything."RELATED: Where Fund Bigwigs Expect To See Stock Gains In 20172017 Personal Finance Action Plan & 2016 Stock Market ReviewClick Here To See A List Of New Buys Of Top Mutual FundsClick Here To See A List Of Latest Sells Of Top Mutual Funds

The buildout of fiber-optic networks by Verizon Communications (VZ), Comcast (CMCSA) and Frontier (FTR), as well as the growth of cloud- computing data centers, has boosted revenue growth at CommScope Holding (COMM), says Citigroup, which initiated coverage on the maker of data connectivity products with a buy rating."We believe fiber to the home (FTTH) trends in North America and Western Europe support our thesis of a turnaround in the Connectivity division, with around 50% of its sales related to telcos," Citigroup analyst Stanley Kovler said in his research report Tuesday. "We believe CommScope is levered to the fiber builds at Verizon, Frontier, and other a large telcos, along with cable companies."Kovler set a price target of 45 on CommScope stock. Kovler says he expects double-digit revenue growth from CommScope.Shares of CommScope closed up 0.5% at 37.21 in the stock market today after rising 1.5% on Monday. CommScope stock, which debuted in 2013, touched an all-time high of 38 on Dec. 12.IBD'S TAKE: CommScope ranks No. 28 in the IBD 50, while Ubiquiti Networks, also part of the Telecom-Infrastructure group, is No. 4. Chipmaker Nvidia tops the IBD 50, which is well-represented by semiconductor, optical and wireless firms.Hickory, N.C.-based CommScope ranks No. 28 in the IBD 50. CommScope stock has shot up 42% in 2016. Shares are trading above its 50-day moving average and are extended beyond a buy point of 33.19 first touched on Nov. 8.CommScope in 2015 acquired TE Connectivity's Broadband Network Solutions (BNS) business, expanding into the "hyper-converged" data center cabling market. Kovler says CommScope might have upside from the buildout of 4G wireless networks in India.IBD's Telecom-Infrastructure group ranks No. 122 out of 197 industry groups. Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) is the top-ranked stock in the group.BroadSoft (BSFT), a company in the same group, could get a boost from a contract win by customer CenturyLink (CTL), said Jefferies, in a separate report. RELATED:Quietly, Telecom System Builders Emerge As LeadersAs Networks Speed Up, Arista Gains Ground On Giant Cisco

Earnings and revenue growth might play a secondary role for telecom stocks in 2017 amid speculation over a potential burst of mergers and acquisitions, but T-Mobile US (TMUS) and Charter Communications (CHTR) stand out for the possible growth of their bottom lines."2017 is setting up to be potentially one of the most dramatic years in recent memory in terms of reshaping the telecom sector," Simon Flannery, Morgan Stanley's longtime telecom analyst, said in a mid-December research report.T-Mobile, controlled by Germany's Deutsche Telekom (DTEGY), figures in many M&A scenarios, along with Sprint (S), Comcast (CMCSA), Verizon Communications (VZ), Dish Network (DISH) and Charter.AT&T (T), meanwhile, is seeking regulatory approval to buy media giant Time Warner (TWX)."The prospect for a sizable number of announced and potential future M&A deals could significantly benefit some companies, while challenging others in the sector," Flannery wrote.IBD'S TAKE: Verizon and AT&T have been favorites of investors looking for high dividends, but there are other options, such as real estate investment trusts (REITs) and banks. Check out IBD's Income Investor for high-dividend-paying stocks.T-Mobile and Sprint stocks have jumped 49% and 140%, respectively, in 2016 through Tuesday, owing partly to their improved operating performance but also on views they could try to merge during a Trump administration. T-Mobile and Sprint, controlled by Japan's SoftBank, are the Nos. 3 and 4 U.S. carriers, behind AT&T and Verizon."We see T-Mobile as being in a strong strategic position, with multiple options, each of which could have very different implications for other industry players," Flannery said. "While we expect a more deregulatory climate, there are significant questions about how accommodative a new DoJ and FCC would be to further industry consolidation."We continue to believe that four-to-three wireless consolidation would be challenging."Wells Fargo's Stephanie Fritzsche on Wednesday became at least the second analyst to lower Q4 subscriber growth estimates for Sprint. She cited aggressive holiday season promotions by Verizon and T-Mobile.Sprint is expected to lose 20 cents per share in the fiscal 2017 ending March 31; but for fiscal 2018 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters estimate a profit of 3 cents.T-Mobile's 2017 earnings are expected to grow 21% to $1.85 per share. Charter's EPS is expected to rise 33% to $5.01 per share, including the acquisition of Time Warner Cable, analysts estimate.Observers speculate Verizon could set its sights on Charter or forge a deeper partnership with the two biggest cable TV firms, Comcast and Charter.Verizon's 2017 EPS is expected to edge up just 2.8% to $4 per share, and AT&T's 4.5% to $2.97 per share, analysts estimate.Comcast will end 2017 with EPS up 8% to $3.77, analysts estimate, while Dish Network's profit is expected to fall 11% to $2.69 per share.Satellite broadcaster Dish, which has amassed 77 MHz of radio spectrum, has been unable to find a wireless partner to sell mobile video services as its core pay-TV business stagnates.CenturyLink's (CTL) 2017 EPS, meanwhile, is expected to slip 4% to $2.30. CenturyLink has agreed to merge with Level 3 Communications (LVLT).AT&T and Verizon stocks have each formed cup bases. AT&T has a buy point of 43.99; Verizon's is 57.05. AT&T stock fell 0.34% to 42.51 the stock market today, while Verizon fell 0.37% to 53.44.RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosVerizon M&A Talk Swirls; Charter Stock Up, Yahoo DownWould T-Mobile Spurn Debt-Laden Sprint For Comcast Offer?

Data, data and more data.Many companies looking to scale-up in today's tech-focused business landscape are creating, manipulating or leveraging data of some kind, and fiber-infrastructure company Zayo Group Holdings (ZAYO) thinks it's at the center of this growing data network.On the company's quarterly earnings call earlier this month, Zayo Chief Executive Dan Caruso touted the company's prospects. He said that with such technologies on the market as augmented reality, cloud computing, data analytics, cybersecurity or — in the near future — quantum computing, there is a huge demand for "tons" more bandwidth."In no scenario does anyone describe there being a technology other than fiber that will be the workhorse of solving for that," Caruso said.One of Zayo's largest customers is Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google Fiber, according to Cowen. And with seemingly endless opportunities to expand its clientele on the horizon, Zayo, one of the only independent nationwide owners of fiber assets, wants to make dark fiber its bread and butter.Dark fiber is essentially unused fiber that is controlled by the purchasing company. That segment accounted for almost 30% of total revenue last quarter, with the fattest adjusted earnings margin at 73%.Barclays analyst Amir Rozwadowski says Zayo's standing in the telecom and cloud ecosystem is strengthening because of fiber. When it comes to the cloud, much of the demand in that space is driven by major public cloud providers Microsoft (MSFT) Azure, Amazon (AMZN) Web Services, Salesforce (CRM) and Google Cloud."The secular demand for fiber remains robust, and management has taken several steps that should position the company well over the longer term," Rozwadowski said in a Nov. 9 report.One of the most important steps the company has taken strategically is to beef up its local ground game while continuing its focus on attracting bigger, national customers."We've changed the way we approach our local dark-fiber opportunities to have strong multifunctional regional teams under regional leaders, for them to work hard in the local markets in all the nooks and crannies of what it takes to exploit those opportunities," Caruso said on the call. "At the same time, you're continuing to be real strong on the more national opportunities that allow us to win the bigger deals and further build out the network."Zayo also has been aggressive with its capital expenditures, with a focus on fiber. JPMorgan analyst Philip Cusick notes that the company's capital program began to accelerate six to eight quarters ago, with expenditures hitting a new high of $208.3 million in the most recent quarter."There is no end in sight to Zayo's aggressive build," Cusick said in a Nov. 9 report. "While revenue has lagged given the long lead time of fiber and small cell programs, we are now approaching the end of some projects and should begin to see the fruits of the labor in the next few quarters."The company's long-term growth prospects have certainly boosted the stock. Its October 2014 initial public offering has been on a steady climb this year, surging more than 75% since hitting an all-time trading low of 19.59 in February.In its latest breakout in September, shares dipped back below the buy point and tested support at the 50-day line before continuing to move higher — similar to action seen among other breakouts this year.The stock hit an all-time high of 35.33 on Nov. 21. Shares ended trading down 1% Monday to 34.70 on the stock market today and are currently 16% past a flat-base entry of 29.86. Once a stock is 20% to 25% past a buy point, that's a signal to take at least partial profits.IBD'S TAKE: While Zayo's stock movement has been strong lately, it still isn't at the top of IBD's computer-networking group. Zayo ranks fourth, with Arista Networks now at the top spot. Shares have been particularly resilient over the past few weeks as the major indexes dropped to nearly four-month lows ahead of the election. And though the company reported a revenue miss when it reported earnings on Nov. 8 — with a 38% gain to $505 million, missing views for $511 million — the stock didn't take much of a hit.Zayo also said in its fiscal first-quarter report that it swung to a profit of 6 cents a share vs. a 6-cent loss last year, beating expectations.But with the bar set high for the company's growth opportunities, analysts have the company's net new-installations figure in focus. For the most recent quarter, Zayo logged $2.3 million in installations, missing forecasts."We believe the dark fiber business segment has been and will be what gets investors excited about Zayo," said Pacific Crest Analyst Michael Bowen in a recent report. "However, we have seen dark fiber consensus estimates move lower for several quarters in a row.On the call, Caruso set a goal of consistently achieving $3 million in net installations. But how long it will take the company to get there is uncertain, and Barclays' Rozwadowski says "the potential for accelerating growth seems to be shifting to a mid-to-long-term prospect (as opposed to within the next few quarters)."JPMorgan's Cusick believes Zayo is on track to reach double-digit revenue growth in the next year. He and Rozwadowski agree that record net bookings of $7.2 million last quarter can be used as a measure of healthy growth prospects."As these bookings are converted to installs, and assuming Zayo's churn levels remain steady, the business could see an increase in its quarterly net install rate," said Rozwadowski.Other companies in the telecom-infrastructure space have been making acquisitions. Verizon Communications (VZ) in February agreed to buy XO Communications for $1.7 billion. And last month CenturyLink (CTL) and Level 3 Communications (LVLT) announced a $34 billion cash-and-stock merger deal.Rozwadowski sees the Century Link-Level 3 as another reason that points to "fiber's rising value proposition to the market."Caruso isn't concerned about the deal."It leaves us as the only independent provider who has significant fiber across the broadly defined U.S., with deep, dense fiber network and intercity fiber, and across many of the city routes," he said on the call. "I think that's really good for Zayo."

The Federal Communications Commission could get involved in the review of AT&T's (T) proposed acquisition of media giant Time Warner (TWX), joining the Department of Justice, says Oppenheimer, which downgraded the telecom conglomerate's stock.Oppenheimer analyst Time Horan says AT&T stock will likely be range bound during the regulatory review, which he expects to drag on into 2018. MoffettNathanson on Monday also forecast that the AT&T-Time Warner review would continue into early 2018. While the DOJ looks at mergers on antitrust grounds the FCC determines whether deals are in the public's interest. MoffettNathanson, like Oppenheimer, also says there's a good chance the FCC will push its way into the AT&T-Time Warner review.Horan, meanwhile, upgraded CenturyLink (CTL) to outperform. CenturyLink last week agreed to acquire Level 3 Communications (LVLT) in a $34 billion cash and stock merger. CenturyLink's stock sold off more than 20% since the deal was announced.IBD'S TAKE: Some investors like telecom companies because many pay high dividends, but there are other options at IBD's Income Investor. "We are downgrading AT&T from outperform to perform as we believe CenturyLink's dividend is relatively more attractive," said Horan in a research report. "We also see the Time Warner merger as facing higher regulatory hurtles and taking more like 15 months to complete vs. nine for CenturyLink-Level 3."AT&T agreed to pay $85.4 billion in cash and stock for Time Warner. Time Warner shareholders will own about 15% of the combined company.If regulators approve the Time Warner acquisition, AT&T will have a national wireless network plus the assets of satellite broadcaster DirecTV, acquired in 2015, and the programming of Time Warner to whisk content to mobile devices."We see the DOJ suing DTV over the Dodgers as an ominous sign," added Horan. "Also, the FCC may initiate a formal review with an eye toward its zero rating (data billing) policy."AT&T's stock tends to take a pause when the company is in the process of closing on a major acquisition, and we suspect a similar outcome and see a better opportunity in CenturyLink currently."AT&T stock rose 0.54% to 37.01 in the stock market today, while CenturyLink stock jumped 3.6% to 24.15.Time Warner's media empire includes HBO and Turner Broadcasting, which has rights to sports telecasts. It also owns Warner Bros. film studio and cable networks TNT, TBS and CNN. Time Warner owns a 10% stake in internet video provider Hulu.RELATED:DOJ Files Antitrust Lawsuit Vs. AT&T-DirecTV Over L.A. Sports ChannelHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosTime Warner Shrugs Off Low AT&T Breakup Fee, Merger Naysayers

Zayo Group Holdings (ZAYO) said it swung to a 6-cent per-share profit in the September quarter vs. a 6-cent loss in the year-earlier period, edging views, but revenue missed consensus estimates.Zayo stock was down a fraction in after-hours trading, after the company released its earnings. Shares rose 1.2% to 32.74 in the regular session in the stock market today.Boulder, Colo.-based Zayo said fiscal Q1 revenue increased 38% to $505 million including acquisitions.Analysts had forecast a 5-cent profit on revenue of $511 million.Zayo operates fiber-optic networks in metropolitan areas, as well as between cities. It leases fiber-optic cables to wireless phone companies and other customers. It also operates data centers.IBD'S TAKE: Some investors like telecom companies because many pay high dividends, but there are other options at IBD's Income Investor. Zayo's shareholders include private equity firms M/C Partners, GTCR, Oak Investment Partners and Columbia Capital.Two firms similar to private equity-controlled Zayo have recently been acquired. Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy XO Communications in February for $1.7 billion, while CenturyLink (CTL) last month announced a merger with Level 3 Communications (LVLT) for $34 billion in cash and stock. The combined firm will be a stronger rival to AT&T (T) and Verizon in the business market, analysts say.RELATED:Windstream, EarthLink Merge As Telecom Takeovers Heat UpHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A Scenarios

CenturyLink (CTL) agreed to buy Level 3 Communications (LVLT) for about $34 billion cash and stock in a deal that will create a more formidable competitor in the market for business telecommunications services.The acquisition values Level 3 at $66.50 a share, the companies said in a statement Monday. That's about 42% above where the Broomfield, Colorado-based company was trading last week, before reports surfaced of a potential acquisition by CenturyLink, which is based in Monroe, Louisiana. The value of the deal includes assumed debt.Level 3 is one of the largest providers used by internet services including Netflix Inc. and Google to route traffic across the web, operations that would bolster CenturyLink's core offerings to businesses. The deal also promises to help CenturyLink by giving it access to about $10 billion in tax credits that Level 3 is carrying on its books, Jennifer Fritzsche, an analyst with Wells Fargo Securities LLC, said last week."Together with Level 3 we will have one of the most robust fiber network and high-speed data services companies in the world," CenturyLink Chief Executive Officer Glen Post said in the statement. He will remain CEO of the combined company, while Level 3 Chief Financial Officer Sunit Patel will be CFO of the new company.CenturyLink, which has been exploring the sale of its data center business, is one of the biggest phone companies in the U.S., formed after CenturyTel bought Embarq in 2009 and acquired Qwest Communications International two years later.The company on Monday reported third-quarter profit of 56 cents a share, after one-time items, beating the average estimate of 55 cents from analysts polled by Bloomberg, on revenue of $4.38 billion, which matched analysts' views. But CenturyLink guided fourth-quarter estimates lower.IBD'S TAKE: CenturyLink is getting a major content-deliver network (CDN) provider, which serves Netflix. Akamai, another big CDN that serves Netflix, had outperformed shares of Level 3. Last week, Akamai reported strong earnings and guidance last week, sending shares soaring.Both companies have contended with growing competition from cable providers and other smaller rivals offering internet and phone connections for businesses. CenturyLink, which also offers residential landline phone and internet services, gets about two-thirds of its revenue from business customers.The acquisition is one of the biggest telecommunications deals of the year. Level 3 had a market value of $19.4 billion at Friday's close and has about $11 billion in debt. CenturyLink was valued at about $16.6 billion and has about $19 billion in debt.CenturyLink shares plunged 12.5% to close at 26.58 on the stock market today. Level 3 jumped nearly 4% to 56.15.Level 3 provides so-called content-delivery network services, particularly to Netflix (NFLX). With more people streaming TV shows and movies over the web, distributors like Netflix have to arrange with a content delivery network to set aside enough servers and transportation capacity for faster load times. By moving the content closer to users and managing traffic patterns viewers can benefit from less delays and buffering of shows.Bank of America and Morgan Stanley advised CenturyLink on the deal. Those two banks have committed to lending the company about $10.2 billion in new secured debt. Evercore Partners issued a fairness opinion while Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and Jones Walker provided legal advice.Level 3 was advised by Citigroup, with a fairness opinion from Lazard Ltd., and Wilkie Farr & Gallagher LLP gave legal advice.

Rural phone company Windstream Holdings (WIN) and Internet service provider EarthLink Holdings (ELNK) agreed to merge in an all-stock $1.1 billion deal, including debt.Windstream expects to issue 93 million shares worth $673 million. Windstream shareholders will own 51% of the combined company, pro forma. The companies expect the deal to close in the first half of 2017. Earthlink had $466 million in debt as of June 30.EarthLink's stock jumped 15% on Friday amid speculation over a merger, to 6.22, but the stock has traded between 7.57 and 5.38 all year on continued losses and declines in revenue.Under deal terms, EarthLink shareholders will receive 0.82 shares of Windstream for each EarthLink share owned. The deal values EarthLink stock at $5.92 a share, below Friday's closing price of 6.22 but about 10% above Thursday's closing price of 5.42. EarthLink stock plunged 10% to finish trading at 5.60 on the stock market today.Windstream stock was flat at 7.23 after jumping 6.8% Friday to 7.24, and shares touched an 18-month high of 10.45 on Sept. 29.IBD'S TAKE: Some investors like telecom companies because many pay high dividends, but there are other options at IBD's Income Investor. "The combined company will have significantly more scale particularly within EarthLink's focus enterprise/mid-market business, which would likely allow it to more effectively compete against many of its much larger competitors," Cowen & Co. analyst Gregory Williams said in a research report. "Finally, we would also expect the combined company to continue to pay Windstream's annual 60-cent-per-share dividend, which has a current yield of 8%, compared to EarthLink's annual 20-cent-per-share dividend, which has a current yield of about 3%."Little Rock, Ark.-based Windstream in April spun off its network assets into a real estate investment trust called Communications Sales and Leasing, in which it retains a nearly 19% stake."The (Windstream-EarthLink) merger would mark another step toward consolidation in the enterprise communications space in an effort to benefit from scale and synergies," said UBS analyst Batya Levi in a research report.Telecom takeovers have heated up. The Windstream-Earthlink merger follows CenturyLink's (CTL) acquisition of Level 3 Communications (LVLT). AT&T (T) last month agreed to buy media giant Time Warner (TWX) in an $85 billion deal.Verizon Communication's (VZ) purchase of web portal Yahoo (YHOO) is expected t close in Q1 2017.RELATED:How Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosAT&T CEO On Time Warner Deal: Aiming To Set Pace In InnovationCenturyLink, Level 3 Stocks Spike; Merger Of Equals?

Telecom business services provider Zayo Group Holdings (ZAYO), viewed by some analyst as a takeover candidate, is expected to swing to a profit when it reports fiscal Q1 earnings after the close Tuesday.Boulder, Colo.-based Zayo operates fiber-optic networks in metropolitan areas as well as between cities. It leases fiber-optic cables to wireless phone companies and other customers. It also operates data centers.Two firms similar to private equity-controlled Zayo have recently been acquired. Verizon Communications (VZ) agreed to buy XO Communications in February for $1.7 billion, while CenturyLink (CTL) last month announced a merger with Level 3 Communications (LVLT) for $34 billion in cash and stock. The combined firm will be a stronger rival to AT&T (T) and Verizon in the business market, analysts say.IBD'S TAKE: Fast-growing companies such as Gigamon and Arista Networks are also takeover candidates, say some analysts. They're among companies in the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks.The Verizon-XO deal, meanwhile, still awaits regulatory approval. Verizon is expected to use XO's network and spectrum as part of its plans to launch 5G services.CenturyLink's purchase of Level 3 "increases the takeout/scarcity/strategic value of Zayo as the only stand-alone nationwide pure-play fiber provider," Colby Synesael, an analyst at Cowen & Co., said in a research report.Zayo is expected to post a 5 cent profit in the September quarter vs. a 6-cent loss in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters estimate revenue will climb 40% to $511 million, including acquisitions.Zayo stock has shot up more than 20% in 2016. Shares of Zayo closed up 2% to 32.36 in the stock market today. Zayo's backers include private equity firms M/C Partners, GTCR, Oak Investment Partners and Columbia Capital.Boulder, Colo.-based Zayo, along with Level 3 Communications, are two telecom survivors of the dot-com bubble. Zayo bought bankrupt firms AboveNet in 2012 and 360networks in 2011 amid numerous acquisitions that it has made since 2007.RELATED:Verizon XO Purchase Could Boost 5G Wireless, 'Small Cell' PlansWindstream, EarthLink Merge As Telecom Takeovers Heat UpHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A Scenarios

As the presidential election race narrows after Friday's surprise FBI announcement, stock investors are finally showing some jitters. Hedges against a market decline surged immediately following reports that the Federal Bureau of Investigation is reviewing files that may be related to an investigation of Hillary Clinton's email practices when she was secretary of state. The ratio of bearish vs. bullish options…

At the urging of Republican lawmakers, FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler late Wednesday removed the "controversial items" from the FCC's Thursday meeting agenda. Republicans wanted to give President-elect Donald Trump time to set up his new administration before the agency vote on such items as a proposal to regulate prices in the $20 billion market for business data services.The move by Republican lawmakers was similar to requests by Democrats in Congress when Barack Obama won the 2008 presidential election.The five-member Federal Communications Commission consists of three Democrats, including Wheeler, and two Republicans.Republican Commissioner Ajit Pai is the front-runner to replace Wheeler, Macquarie Securities analyst Amy Yong said in a research note."During the last presidential transition, the commission chairman wisely heeded the will of Congress in setting aside any remaining controversial agenda items for the next Congress and administration to consider," said Republican FCC Commissioner Mike O'Rielly in a statement on Tuesday. "I thank the current leadership of both Senate and House commerce committees for calling this precedent to everyone's attention today, and expect that Chairman Wheeler will honor their request."IBD'S TAKE: Comcast stock has gained 7.5% since Donald Trump's surprise election as president on Nov. 8, and Charter stock is up, too. Learn more at IBD Stock Checkup.The FCC in October adopted new "opt-in" consumer data-privacy rules governing broadband services, giving Wheeler a win after he shelved a controversial proposal on cable-TV set-top boxes last month.Analysts expect Trump and a Republican-controlled Congress to ease up on regulation after Wheeler battled the telecom industry on broadband, internet and other issues.Business data services had been on the agenda for Thursday's FCC meeting. The FCC rules would regulate new entrants in the market — cable-TV firms such as Comcast (CMCSA) and Charter Communications (CHTR) as well as the biggest providers of business data services, including AT&T (T), Verizon Communications (VZ), and local phone companies CenturyLink (CTL) and Frontier Communications (FTR). Republicans oppose the pricing regulation.The high-speed connections are used for retail outlets, ATMs and cell towers. Smaller telecom firms such as Level 3 Communications (LVLT) and Cogent Communications (CCOI) sometimes rent the "special access" lines to serve their customers. Some renters have complained over long-term contracts and termination fees.Comcast stock rose 0.7% to close at 67.47 on the stock market today. Shares are forming a flat base with a buy point of 68.46. Charter stock also gained 0.7%, to 261.99, on Wednesday, after almost trigging the 8%-decline sell rule earlier. Charter stock broke out of a cup base at a 280.05 buy point on Thursday, but shares fell below their 50-day line on Tuesday.RELATED:Comcast: Does Trump Win Portend Regulatory Rollback?FCC Adopts Privacy Rules: Will Facebook, Google Gain Vs. ISPs?AT&T, Comcast Cheer: FCC's Wheeler Pulls Set-Top VoteNet Neutrality Upheld: Big Win For FCC, Netflix; AT&T Vows To Appeal

Stocks opened higher Monday, as data showed improvements in consumer income and spending during September.Dow industrials rose a fraction while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq added 0.2%, aided by Micron Technology (MU) and Check Point Software (CHKP).Merger news powered some significant early moves on the stock market today, while a heavy week of earnings reporting set off to a quiet start.Baker Hughes (BHI) rose 1% and General Electric (GE) traded up 1% after the two companies agreed to a merger of GE's gas and oil services business with Baker Hughes. GE shareholders would own 62.5% of the new company; Baker Hughes shareholders would own 37.5% and would receive a one-time cash dividend of $17.50 per share.Drilling contractor Nabors Industries (NBR) rose 1% at the open, after announcing a joint venture to manage onshore drilling operations in Saudi Arabia. Nabors is pulled back from an Oct. 19 high, after clearing a cup-with-handle base in September.Level 3 Communications (LVLT) bolted 4% higher after cable and telecom services provider CenturyLink (CTL) said it would buy the Broomfield, Colo.-based company for $34 billion.  Both CenturyLink and Level 3, a network services provider, serve primarily commercial customers.CenturyLink also reported third-quarter results, narrowly topping analyst targets, but guiding fourth-quarter earnings and revenue below consensus views. CenturyLink shares tumbled 9%. Last week Level 3 surged 15% on deal buzz, while CenturyLink climbed almost 8%.Team Health Holdings (TMH) surged 16% after confirming it had agreed to be taken private by Blackstone Group in a deal valued at $6.1 billion.  Team Health, which provides outsourced healthcare services, has been in a deep consolidation since August 2015.Check Point Software added 4.5% at the open. The Israel-based security software developer scored a nice third-quarter earnings and revenue beat. The stock climbed back above its 40-week moving average in heavy trade on Friday, possibly starting the right side of a six-month consolidation.October ends and November begins with a heavy week of economic news, including the Federal Open Market Committee's two-day meeting that begins Tuesday, and the Labor Department's October payrolls report on Friday. Overseas, the Reserve Bank of Australia, the Bank of Japan and the Bank of England all have policy decisions due this week.Monday's news started with personal income rose, which 0.3% in September, according to the Commerce Department, up from a 0.2% gain in August but below consensus views for a 0.4% rise. Spending jumped 0.5%, a sharp increase from August's revised 0.1% slip, and in line with forecasts. Prices rose 0.2%, according to the PCE Price Index, meeting expectations. Core price growth slowed to 0.1%, also as expected.Kingsbury International's Chicago purchasing managers index is set for release at 9:45 a.m. ET.Oil futures dipped almost 1%, leaving West Texas Intermediate trading well below $49 a barrel. Gold was also down, below $1,275 an ounce. The dollar strengthened. So did bonds, trimming 2 basis points from the 10-year yield, to 1.83%.Asia markets posted a rare uniform finish with leading indexes in Hong Kong, Shanghai and Tokyo all down 0.1%. Stocks in Europe were under mild pressure in afternoon trade, with the CAC 40 in Paris down 0.7%, the DAX Frankfurt off 0.3% and London's FTSE 100 showing a 0.5% loss.RELATED:Baker-Hughes, General Electric Gas & Oil Business CombineCenturyLink Will Buy Level 3 For $34 Billion

The major stock indexes rose slightly near midday Monday as another busy week of earnings and economic data got underway.The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 were up about 0.3% while the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking lower than Friday's levels in the stock market today — more so on the Nasdaq.The Fed meets on Tuesday and Wednesday. Not much is expected from the meeting with the election right around the corner. The October jobs report is due Friday.West Texas intermediate crude oil futures took another hit. The December contract lost nearly 3% to $47.43 a barrel. Apparently, there's still disagreement among OPEC members over how to implement supply cuts.Another merger made headlines Monday when CenturyLink (CTL) agreed to buy Level 3 Communications (LVLT) for around $34 billion in cash and stock. Shares of CenturyLink tumbled 12%, while Level 3 picked up nearly 5%.Meanwhile, Constellation Brands (STZ) moved higher on news the company is acquiring the Grupo Modelo brewery in Mexico for $600 million. Grupo Modelo is a unit of Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD). Shares of Constellation Brands rose 1%, while Anheuser-Busch InBev lost 2% after crumbling nearly 8% last week on earnings.Inside the IBD 50, Paycom Software (PAYC) eased 0.2% to 51.54. After a breakout over an early entry of 51.56, a handle is taking shape and may create a 52.90 entry. Earnings are due Tuesday after the close. Competitor Ultimate Software (ULTI) also reports Tuesday after the close.IBD'S TAKE: Want to learn about Paycom's business of human capital management software? Check out this recent New America story.Stamps.com (STMP) picked up 3% ahead of its earnings report Thursday after the close. It's working on a base with a 100.42 buy point. Note that Stamps.com is a heavily shorted stock, which means a relatively high number of investors are betting on weakness in the stock.RELATED:CenturyLink Will Buy Level 3 For $34 Billion In Cash, StockDivided OPEC, Other Big Producers Fail To Agree On Supply Curbs

Shares in local phone company CenturyLink (CTL) and Level 3 Communications (LVLT) spiked on reports they're in advanced talks to merge.Broomfield, Colo.-based Level 3 operates one of the world's largest internet backbones. Level 3 in 2014 acquired TW Telecom, becoming a stronger rival to AT&T (T) and Verizon Communications (VZ) in providing telecom services to businesses. A deal could come within weeks, the Wall Street Journal reported.CenturyLink morphed into the nation's third largest local phone company, behind Verizon and AT&T, by purchasing Qwest and Embarq. Centurylink's data center business has been up for sale. Verizon is reportedly close to selling off its data centers to Equinix (EQIX).Neither CenturyLink or Level 3 Communications owns a wireless phone network. Comcast (CMCSA) and Alphabet (GOOGL) unit Google has also been viewed as a possible buyer of Level 3 Communications.The deal may be structured as a merger of equals. Level 3 Communications has a market cap of around $18 billion, while CenturyLink's is over $17 billion.CenturyLink jumped 9.7% to close at 31.00 on the stock market today, hitting 33.45 intraday. Level 3 leapt 10.55% to 51.87.RELATED:Verizon Seen Near Deal To Sell Data Centers To Equinix For $3.5 BillionLevel 3 Stock Surging; Could Google Or Comcast Surface As Buyer?
